 ABSTRACT The World Bank; and other international aid agencies have expeaded their commitments in recent years to small-scale agriculture. The sociological and instit:utional problems of implementing such projects have tended to receive insufficient attention from donors or host governments. This has been especially true of implementation at the field level. Tnere are many opportunities to strengthen local institutions and improve the quality and relevance of services by drawing on private enterprise, voluntary organization; and associations of local farmers, as well as improving the performance of government agencies. Many combinations are available to strengthen local action capabilities. The cost-effectiveness of agricultural projects can tbe increased by innovations in the .ield level staffing of government agencies that provide services to rural publics. It is at the point of contact between field representatives of government agencies and local publics that agricultural projects often break down. Instead of relying primarily on inadequate numbers of relatively costly subprofessional civil servants, governments should experiment with less formally trained and m,uch less costly, local persons to extend the outreach of agricultural services to groups that could otherwise not be served. The World Bank has already begun to support projects that employ "paraprofessional" staEf in such diverse fields as agricultural extension, irrigation, livestock, and forestry development. Drawing from such projects and from much more extensive experience in health administration, a number of institutional and sociological lessons emerge for improving the cost-effectiveness- of paraprofessional staffing. Such lessons include: 1) consultation with project beneficiaries in the choice of paraprofessionals, 2) the employment of female paraprofessionals to assist in the performance of farming roles normally played by women, 3) preservice and frequent refresher training in practical, job-related information and skills, and 4) reliable referral, logistical, and supervisory support for paraprofessional staff. Rural service centers can provide useful and convenient facilities for the location of related experimentation, training and support services. Certain changes in administrative procedures may be required, including the redefinition of subprofessional roles and appropriate retraining to emphasize supervisory functions and skills, rather than the front-line provision of services which become increasingly the responsibility of paraprofessionals.
 Paraprofessionals selected by, compensated by, and accountable to local organizations and associations of farmers (e.g., water users' associations) can increase the relevance and cost-effectiveness of services while enhancing local self-reliance. In paying more attention to the sociological dimensions of development, the Bank has begun to incorporate local organizations into its project designs, but has not matched this interest with complementary attention to field-level management and staffing problems. Donor agencies can strengthen the field staffing of agricultural projects by sponsoring training facilities and assisting with training materials and methodologies and by building process monitoring into projects. The latter should focus on local implementation, including the performance of the specific combinations of field-staffing methods designed for the project in question. Process monitoring facilitates organizational learning and the incremental improvement of field operations.

 I. STAFFING AND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION The purpose of this inquiry is to examine feasible and cost-effective ways to handle field staffing in agricultural development projects. Field staff effectiveness is paramount for accomplishing the social changes envisaged by rural development projects. Most agricultural projects assisted by the World Bank in recent years are designed to enhance the productivity, employment opportunities, and incomes of small-scale cultivators; and pastoralists. Achieving these goals requires improvements in the quality, relevance, reliability, and access of farmers to such services and resources as extension information, credit, production inputs, processing, and marketing. Some of these agricultural support services and resources can be provided through private sector channels and some by the initiatives of organized farmers, but much of the responsibility must be assumed by governments and their bureaucratic agencies. The principal task of contacting rural people and delivering these services falls on the field staffs of government agencies. These field staffs are often insufficient in number to maintain effective contact with all the families they are expected to serve. All too often these technicians are indifferently trained, inadequately equipped, poorly paid, and undermotivated. Condemned to dead-end jobs in rural areas, they are far removed from the sophisticated planners and high-level civil servants in capital cities who negotiate foreign assistance projects on
 - 2 - behalf of their governments. Yet the success of agricultural projects in which governments and foreign donors invest scarce financial and administrative resources depends, in large measure, on tne performance of these field staffs. Agricultural projects, especially those oriented to small and marginal farmers, are especially sensitive to the quality of implementation. In addition to making services accessible to their intended beneficiaries, project managers must ensure that such services are, in fact, accepted and used by the farmers. Most of the services provided in agricultural projects require some changes in their behavior. Farmers cannot be compelled, but must be induced and convinced that new or allegedly improved services, resources or techniques will actually benefit them and that the changes required in such areas as cultivation methods, water management, or marketing procedures are worth the costs and the risks to them of accepting the changes. It is the field staffs of the agricultural service agencies on whom governments and donors must rely not only to deliver new or improved services, but also to persuade farmers to accept them and to work with farmers to adapt them to specific local conditions. The World Bank's commitment to agricultural and rural development projects has escalated more than tenfold in current dollar terms during the past two decades, from an annual lending level of less than $400 million in the early 1960s to more than $3 billion in FY82. Government financial commitments for agricultural services have also increased considerably in many countries. This has imposed enormous burdens on the hard-pressed budgets of developing countries, especially for the recurrent costs of field personnel whose numbers have increased in order to staff new and expanded agricultural activities. As numbers expand, governments in many cases have been unable to
 maintain the quality of agricultural field staff, whose training, technical capacities and communication skills were in any case quite modest. The high costs and indifferent performance of field personnel have induced some governments to consider several measures to relieve the financial burden, while continuing to expand needed services at acceptable levels of perfonnance to less advantaged rural producers. Three such measures are: 1) to entrust the provision of some services, especially the supply of inputs and marketing of products, to networks of private commercial dealers; 2) to engage locally resident, low cost, non-civil service persons, an innovation we designate as "paraprofessional," to perform a variety of service delivery and associated functions; and 3) to induce local groups of farmers or village communities to assume greater responsibility for the acquisition, provision and management of agricultural and rural development services. These methods dc, not imply that governments can or should eliminate services, but, rather that more cost-effective ways can be found to implement the goals of increasing productivity and generating employment for the small cultivators, who will continue to constitute rural majorities in most low income countries. The purpose of this paper is to explore management methods that can increase the cost-effectiveness of government and donor investments and expenditures in small-scale agriculture through innovative staffing patterns. It is part of the conventional wisdom that development projects tend to be well designed, but unfortunately, are often poorly implemented. This is a convenient myth to explain away the neglect of sociological, administrative and institutional feasibility analysis during the preparation and appraisal of projects. That projects which directly affect the interests and require changes in behavior among farmers can be competently designed in the absence
 -4- of any consultation with the farmers concerned or with their representatives - for most agricultural development projects are in fact designed top down without such consultation or involvement - is an interesting question which need not detail us here; but that many such projects are, in fact, poorly implemented is supported by massive testimony of knowledgeable observers. The details of implementation that are so frequently overlooked in project design include many that involve action on the ground -- logistics, financial procedures, schedules, and especially staffing. Often project designers, having dealt with the major issues of finance, technology, organizational placement, and estimated benefits, assume that such operational details as field-level staffing do not require the time and attention of senior officials of donor agencies or governments and can be worked out by subordinate managers at a later date. Unfortunately, the neglect of implementation planning at the design stage often contributes to project failure because the administrative assumptions in the design are not spelled out and the envisaged social change proves to be operationally unfeasible; and when they are feasible in principle, they are often botched by casual or indifferent attention to field-level management. Non-performance and poor performance of field personnel are often cited as deficiencies in project implementation. Yet this is not an irremediable problem. The performance of field staffs can be upgraded and their outreach can be extended by good personnel management practices supplemented by staffing innovations that have already been developed and tested in several projects, including some sponsored by the World Bank. These staffing innovations using local, non-civil service personnel or paraprofessionals do involve additional operating or recurrent costs for aid donor and financially hard-pressed governments. But these costs are modest compared with the costs of normal civil service staffing. Moreover, in many
 - 5 - cases the provision of services can be shared with private sector networks and with project beneficiaries at considerable saving to government and at no cost in effectiveness or efficiency. Field-level staffing and related metnods of service delivery are an important dimension of institutional development and social change at the grass roots. It is one of those "software" components of project implementation that has been neglected in many foreign-assistance activities by governments and donors alike. Prior to the preparation of this paper, a monograph was produced by the writer and several associates at Cornell on Paraprofessionals in Rural Development. 1/ This monograph reviewed the state-of-the-art in the use of indigenous, non-civil service personnel to expand the outreach of government agencies in rural areas and to improve the quality of their interactions and exchanges with local publics. Though most of the published data dealt with community health workers, experiments were identified which app'Ly this innovation in other sectors, including agriculture and forestry. * Because of the possibility that the paraprofessional method could be useful for World Bank sponsored agricultural projects, the writer was invited to examine Bank projects which included this innovation. More rhan twenty such projects were identified and reviewed; the term "paraprofessional" was not used in Bank documents, but the roles were there. These projects are listed in Appendix A. * Those interested in more factual field information than can be incorporated in the present paper, may find it in four volumes of country case studies on patterns and experiences of paraprofessionaL's work (Sri Lanka, the Philippines, Senegal and Upper Volta) published in the Cornell University "Special Series on Paraprofessionals."
 -6- In the course of interviews with World Bank personnel, it became evident that paraprofessionals could most adequately be treated as part of the broader problem of field staffing in tne implementation of agricultural projects. Though specific data from the Bank's experience are drawn from projects that employ paraprofessionals, the projects reviewed by this author represent only a small fraction of Bank-supported agricultural projects. My more general observations came from interviews with Bank officials, my previous study of parc-rofessional activities, and many years as a participant observer of rural development and development administration in various countries.
 II. THE NEGLECT OF FIELD-LEVEL STAFFING One of the leasr: satisfactory elements in development projects are the field-level bureaucr;ats directly in touch with members of the public for whose benefit services are designed and provided. This neglect is particularly evident in the literature on the agricultural and rural sectors in developing countries. 2/ It reflects lack of interest and low priority by governments and development assistance agencies. The consequence is that members of the field staffs of government bureaucracies working in agriculturally-related activities tend to be undertrained, burdened with more tasks than they can handle, poorly supervised, under-supplied with the information and the supplies they need to assist their clients, poorly compensated and consequently ill-motivated. Because they, as well as their publics, know that they cannot perform satisfactorily they often protect themselves by avoiding contact, by setting up or enforcing complex paper routines, and by confining themselves in their offices. Often their numbers are insufficient to serve more than a smaLl percentage of the farmers and farm families in their nominal area of responsibility. Consequently, their services cannot be effective; they resolve this dilemma by confining their efforts to a small number of the better endowed, more "progressive" fanaers or to those near the larger settlements who are easiest to reach. 3/ Yet the effecti'veness of most agricultural projects, especially those oriented to the majority of rural people who are smallholders, depends on their ability to reach i:hese large and often dispersed publics with information and other services which can help them increase their productivity and raises their incomes. Project goals can seldom be achievecl by occasional and superficial contact because they require the innovation or adoption of
 - 8 - unfamiliar farming practices, which entail risks to resource constrained farmers, the consequences of which cannot be predicted in advance. The need is for continuing service and for two-way communication so that needs, innovations, and responses can flow steadily from farmers to government agencies and vice versa. Most developing country governments are not yet equipped to provide services to their rural publics in this mode. Agency headquarters tend to be well equipped and staffed with capable and qualified personnel. At provincial headquarters the quality of staff and equipment is quite respectable. But the closer one approached tne field where services must actually be delivered, the less qualifird and the more poorly equipped and motivated are the staff who bear the ultimate burden of interacting with farmers, the point at whicn projects pay off or fail. The rapid expansion of agricultural services, often prompted by the resources made available through aid agencies, has multiplied the presence in the field of poorly equipped and ineffective staff. In general policy statements and analyses of development problems, World Bank documents and staff recognize the importance of field-level staffing. 4/ The Rural Development Sector Policy Paper of February 1975 devoted a page and a half to this topic, and dealt at similar length with tne closely related subject of local participation. 5/ The 1980 World Development Report emphasizes the same themes: "Improving administration at the periphery is far more complex and difficult than administrative reform at the center, a task that has itself often proved intractable. Many of the poor are hard to reach through conventional public programs, and the end-of-the-line workers may not be motivated to break the social, linguistic and physical barriers that separate them from the poor. Supply lines for textbooks or medicine may be continually breaking down, and the necessary technical support may be lacking. But these and similar difficulties must be overcome to reach the poor; that usually means improving organization at the grass roots." 6/
 - 9 - In a sociological analysis of Bank assisted projects, (ernea has called attention to the need for systematically building farmers,' organizations at the grass-roots level and for: "practical methodologies for carrying it out; of a social technology for building farmers groups.. .National governments and international technical agencies are not geared toward such an orientation and individual 'development experts' from an outside international agency cannot change that situation by themselves; moreover, in many cases those experts are not equipped with systemat:ic expertise about this side of the development effort.. .This lack of personnel exists primarily at the project level.." 7/ Despite growing recognition of these issues in Bank policy statements and studies, a review of on-going projects indicates a lag in the application of these concepts to concrete country projects. Institutional analyses in project appraisal reports tend to be ifragmentary and to focus on the senior staffs of ministries, departments or project organizations, often passing over lightly the networks of operat:ing personnel at the grass roots level. The implicit assumption, springing from conventional organization theory, is that if senior personnel are technically and managerially well qualified and highly motivated, they will ensure that staffing and the details of staff performance lhroughout the organization are adequate to their tasks. Senior staff are expected to install logistical supervisory and information systems that provide the intended outputs and ensure quality control. Field-level staffing is often treated as a residual concern that will somehow be taken care of at a subsequent time by medium-level managers. Given what is known about pluralism among and within bureaucratic agencies and the political dimensions of administrative behavior, especially in rural areas, this command model is simply not a valid basis for project design. The legitimate concern of Bank staff and of member
 - 10 - governments to limit the recurrent costs of projects, especially of projects that are necessarily labor-intensive, is sometimes cited as another reason for evading the problems of field-staffing. The effectiveness of agricultural development projects largely depends on the interaction at the boundary between the government's bureaucratic agencies and the publics they are intended to serve. This is partly a question of numbers, but more than numbers is involved. Project effectiveness also depends on the training, equipment, attitudes, morale and supervision of field staffs, the system of incentives and rewards under which they operate, and their behavior toward the publics they encounter. Since farmers can seldom be compelled but must usually be induced to accept advice or services from government agents, the latter need negotiating and political, as well as technical skills. Such concerns are little evident in the Bank's project documentation, especially in appraisal reports, despite their importance to project success. The principal exceptions to these observations are the Bank sponsored T and V Extension projects which are explicitly concerned with organization, staffing and supervision at the field level. Whatever else may be said about this still evolving system, these seem to be among the first of the Bank's agricultural projects that specifically and systematically address field-staffing and the nexus between government personnel and their publics. 8/ Institutional changes and specific improvements at the grass roots are often difficult because they depend in some measure on government-wide processes - on national level personnel systems, on general financial procedures, on ministry level procurements systems, and on methods of supervision that are determined in capital cities. A common
 - 11 - prescription, therefore, is to begin by reforming government-wide administrative systems on the premise that the center determines what can happen at the periphery. Three decades of experience with efforts at government-wide administrative reforms have demonstrated, however, that such efforts encounter stubborn vesited interests and that even when government-wide reforms are formally adopted they are very slow to be carried out and are often blocked in the interstices of bureaucracy before they ever reach the field. While field-level reforms may be inhibited by government-wide administrative and managerial procedures and by associated bureaucratic interest groups, experi'ence had demonstrated that there are usually degrees of freedom for specific improvements in project operations in the field, especially if these improvements are initially promoted and encouraged by donor agerncies. Administrative entrepreneurship can often be evoked at project and program levels, even in spite of government-wiae procedures. Indeed thet pressure of project needs and demonstrated success of innovations at the field level can provide further leverage for more comprehensive ministry-wide and government-wide reforms. While the Bank is now contemplating more attention to government-wide reforms and there may be circumstances when this indeed is the most effective strategic point of entry, many more improvements in methods of implementation and in institutional development have been induced in specific project and program contexts than in efforts at system-wide reform. There is no reason to believe that improvements in field-level staffing and in related institutional developments should not be attempted in conjunction with specific agricultural projects. If they can be combined with macro-level reforms, so much the better, but the main focus should continue to be on those specific, incremental changes that
 - 12 - are needed and appear to be feasible to make particular projects and programs function more effectively and at acceptable costs. The field-level capabilities that must be tapped and encouraged should not, however, be confined to bureaucratic personnel. They should also allow greater scope for activity and responsibility by non-governmental groups including the beneficiary publics themselves.
 - 13 - III. PATTERNS OF FIELD-LEVEL STAFFING There are three main methods for the staffing of field services and all of them are evident in agricultural activities. Within each method there are distinctive variations, some of which will be identified and discussed in this paper. Method one involves the use of subprofessional staff in direct contact with members of the public. Method two employs agency paraprofessionals responsible to a government department as links between the subprofessional and the public. Method three draws on members of local organizations, community paraprofessionals, to perform locally required services and link the local organizations of farmers with the subprofessional representative of the government agency. We shall outline each of these methods. Before discussing the common methods of field staffing, reference should be made to the role of agricultural professionals in providing services to rural households. It is unlikely that fully qualified profe3sionals - agronomists, veterinarians, plant scientists and others with university degrees or their equivalent and the status that these confer - will be widely present on the ground in direct contact with local farmers and their families. They are seldom in evidence, except as members of training or supervisory cadres. They are usually too expensive and too few in number to be used for direct service, especially to small farmers; the social and cognitive distance between them and uneducated, low-status farmers is often so great as to inhibit effective communication and cooperation; and most of them refuse to live and work in rural communities. Except in training, supervisory and occasionally group organizational roles, full fledged professionals do not constitute a significant component of field-level staffing.
 - 14 - Subprofessionals Service delivery and public contact are usually the functions of subprofessionals. These are men (occasionally women) who are graduates of secondary schools and of two- or three-year technical institutes or colleges. Normally they are full-time and pensionable public functionaries, members of a state bureaucracy with the status and perquisites of civil servants. They receive technical and usually managerial guidance from, and are accountable to, professional members of the same department or agency. The conventional and most common pattern of service delivery (method 1) involves the subprofessional, e.g., the agricultural assistant, veterinary assistant, or cooperative officer, in direct contact with members of the public. These contacts can be on a one-to-one basis, though usually the staff-client ratios in smallholder areas makes this impossible or infrequent and necessarily superficial. Otherwise, contact occurs with and through organized groups of farmers and their families, a topic that will be explored later in this paper. Paraprofessionals As defined by the Cornell research team, paraprofessionals are persons indigenous to the service area with limited formal schooling and limited pre-service training; while they may be part of an organized public or voluntary agency, they do not enjoy the status or the perquisites of civil servants; they are in direct contact with the public, they often work part-time, and their compensation, if any, is usually quite modest. 9/ The paraprofessional method relies on indigenous people to be intermediaries between the subprofessional civil servant and members of
 - 15 - the public. Though they- have been in evidence for many years, paraprofessionals represent an underutilized resource in many agricultural and other rural development projects. As the last link in the state's bureaucratic structure, the agency paraprofessional (method 2) extends the outreach of the government agency so that through him or her it can maintain direct and more intensive contact with a much larger number of farmers and their families than would be possible for the much more costly subprofessional. The paraprofessional works under the guidance and supervision of the subprofessional. His access to the information and resources of the government agency is usually through this channel. The objective of the paraprofessional system is to extend the range of public services in a cost-effective way. The main risk is that the quality of service may be attenuated by the limited skills and knowledge of the paraprofessional. For this reason, as we shall see, the paraprofessional role can usually be effective only if it is supported by reliable training, supervisory, and logistical arrangements. Agency paraprofessionals can develop the relations with their publics in two ways: they can transact directly with individual farmers and members of their families in the areas to which they are assigned; or they can work with and through formal or informal organizations of their publics, such as farmers' organizations, water users' associations, cooperatives., or credit unions. In the latter case, the paraprofessional may have to help activate or even form these organizations and be responsive to their group interests, if he or she is to benefit from their ability to "retail" information and services to their members or to mobilize local resources on behalf of the project.
 - 16 - Where groups of farmers are reasonably well organized, they are able to provide a number of services for themselves through their collective resources or by mutual assistance. Usually, however, these organizations of small farmers cannot be entirely self-reliant; they lack some of the skills or information required to manage their affairs or to transact with government agencies or private firms on which they depend for needed resources. Instead of depending on paraprofessionals responsible to a government agency, the community paraprofessional (method 3) is selected by and accountable directly to the local organization to which he or she belongs and to its members. The government agency must usually help to train and enhance the skills of the local organization's paraprofessionals and provide them with other back-stopping services. Private voluntary organizations are often useful intermediaries in support of community paraprofessionals. The important distinction is that the community paraprofessionals are responsible and accountable to their neighbors, not to a bureaucratic agency. To sum up, these are the three basic patterns of local-level staffing: (1) the subprofessional civil service technician in direct contact with the public; (2) the combination subprofessional-agency paraprofessional; and (3) the community paraprofessional linking with the subprofessional. There are, of course, numerous variations to these main patterns. One set of examples are the T and V extension projects. There the village extension worker (VEW) is clearly a subprofessional (technical training, civil service status), a "professional extension worker" as defined by the Indian Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives. 10/ The contact farmer is a pale but still palpable embodiment of the agency paraprofessional. In the Bank-assisted Indonesian 16th Irrigation Project, the project design provides for two levels
 - 17 - of paraprofessionals working under the guidance of subprofessionals: the "key farmers" who are agency paraprofessionals, and the "water user association representatives" who appear to be community paraprofessionals selected by WUA members. A Bank-sponsored study of village drinking water systems identified the need for "field assistants," a type of agency paraprofessional to supervise local self-help construction activities, and for "local artisans," which would be a kind of community paraprofessionals in charge of handling minor repair and maintenance tasks. 11/ Other combinations are certain to emerge and one useful. task for future research is to identify more precisely the combinations cf field-level staffing that are appropriate for different local service requirements.
 - 18 - IV. WORLD BANK EXPERIENCE WITH FIELD-LEVEL STAFFING IN AGRICULTURAL PROJECTS The information available to me indicates that the World Bank assisted projects have not usually attached high priority to this subject in project design or implementation. This view was confirmed in a number of interviews with Bank officials. It was reinforced by my review and analysis of 20 or so project appraisal reports which were brought to my attention because they included paraprofessionals. The appraisal reports included in this rather small group of projects were very thin in their discussion of field-level staffing, though one might have expected projects that incorporate paraprofessionals to be especially sensitive to this subject. The staff appraisal reports that were reviewed seldom contained more than a few sentences on field-level staffing and the same can be said for the project performance audit reports. The written information was so fragmentary and incomplete that it is often difficult to answer some of the more common and obvious questions about staffing, practical questions which governments and donor agencies must perforce deal with in the design and management of projects. Perhaps more written documentation about field staffing is available than I was able to locate, but my impression is that this subject has not been of great interest to appraisal missions. There appear to be four kinds of Bank-sponsored agricultural projects in which field staffing has included paraprofessionals: livestock projects employing paraveterinarians; social forestry activities using "motivators;" irrigation projects involving ditch tenders and other local skills associated
 - 19 - with small water management units; and extension,the great majority of which incorporate some version of the T and V system, and in which paraprofessional roles are variously designated as contact farmers, farmer-foremen, promotors, model farmers or demonstration farmers. In its previous study on paraprofessionals, the CornelL report identified a set of eight functions or activities in which paraprofessionals participate. With minor modifications, these are common functions of field-level staff in agricultural projects. To what extent do field personnel in Bank assisted projects become involved in these activities? The incomplete data derived primarily from design documents indicate the main activities which field staff are expected to perform, but seldom the proportion or relative weight of such activities: 1. Service delivery - This covers the provision of physical resources, technical information, or managerial skills that were not previously present and might not otherwise be available to local farmers. All the projects examined in this survey provided some incremental services to their publics. The most common was information on improved cropping practices (T and V system), but they range from drugs for the treatment of animal diseases to feed supplements, credit, fertilizers, pesticides, storage and marketing facilities, and the provision of seedlings. In small irrigation projects, the community paraprofessionals are in such service roles as ditchtenders, water masters and bookkeepers. Some services are provided to particular groups; for example, the Benin Atacora P'roject had a special component oriented to the needs of village women.,
 - 20 - 2. Education - Paraprofessionals and other field-level personnel are frequently involved in spreading information about improved practices and new technologies. An authoritative review of 39 low-cost AID-financed health projects indicated that 79X were involved in community education 12/. Non-formal transfer of information is the main activity of the village extension worker-contact farmer combination in the T and V system. All T and V projects emphasize practical information, including, in the several T and V projects in India and the Nepal Hill Food Production Project, farm management training. In all the projects in this sample, non-formal education in the form of transfer of knowledge was a major component of the subprofessional and the paraprofessional roles. Information transfer is, of course, the most vulnerable role for paraprofessionals because of their limited technical expertise. Yet recent experiments, such as ICTA in Guatamala and the PNIA project in Honduras reported by Whyte, indicate that ordinary small farmers have much useful local information to contribute to the improvement of farming practices in their distinctive micro environments and that their representatives (community paraprofessionals) can be useful bridges between their fellow farmers and agricultural scientists. 13/ The experience of the Comilla project yielded similar results. The paraprofessionals need scientific support and some training in communication skills; with these resources they can be effective as two-way commnunicators of useful, practical information.

PROBLEMS IN THE EMPLOYMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF FIELD PERSONNEL Though the Bank staff appraisal and project performance audit reports contain little detailed information about field-level staff, certain specific bits of information, combined with what is known from previous research about employment practices at this level, permit a number of general observations. A. Status an,d Compensation Subprofessional workers are normally part of the state bureaucracy, full-time, salaried and pensionable civil servants. Their salaries tend to be much lower than professionals, but much higher than the annual incomes of most of the farmers they serve. They have job and income security, medical benefits and retirement rights. Because they represent a major recurrent burden on hard-pressed government budgets, it is important that their numbers be limited and that they be assigned to tasks which cannot be equally well performed by much less costly paraprofessionals, local organizations, or the private sector. The structure of subprofessional employment often provides few prospects for promotion or career development, since professional posts are restricted to persons with the requisite professional (formal.) education. The deleterious effects of dead-end positions on morale and on performance can De relieved by establishing subprofessional career lines that reward good performance but do not require professional education. When this expedient is limited, the subprofessional salary range should be elongated. in order to allow satisfactory performance to be rewarded by periodic salary increases throughout a full career. Non-material incentives, including opportunities for refresher training and job enrichment (training in new skills and procedures), can help to sustain employee interest and morale.
 - 30 - The working conditions and status of paraprofessionals are quite variable. They may be part-time (contact farmers) or full-time (para-veterinarians in the Eastern Senegal Livestock Development Project); unsalaried, except for inputs used in demonstrations (T and V contact farmers) or compensated by stipends or honorariums (West Bengal Social Forestry "motivators") or by sales of inputs (drugs in the Niger Livestock Project). Paraprofessionals do not enjoy the status, security, perquisites, regular salaries or retirement prospects of civil servants. Though extensions of bureaucratic agencies, agency paraprofessionals are not themselves bureaucrats; the resultant flexibility, much lower costs, and wider outreach are an important part of the case for using paraprofessionals and for limiting the growth of less cost-effective subprofessional cadres. Some agency paraprofessionals, however, begin to aspire to civil service status as a reward for faithful service so that they can participate in the job security, pension rights, and career advancement available to civil servants. But since they are locally based and part-time, a stipend or hororarium plus local prestige usually constitutes sufficient material reward for their service. The source of salary or honorariums is usually the government, invariably for subprofessionals and normally for agency paraprofessionals. The local group or community may be asked to make contributions in kind or in profits from the sale of goods and services to provide some compensation for paraprofessionals. Where subprofessional staff are employed by local organizations (e.g., Farmer's Associations in Taiwan) tney are paid by the local organization. Similarly, honoraria for persons serving as community paraprofessional in such projects as the water users' associations in the Philippines are expected to be contributed by the local organization. In the Bank-sponsored Mali-sud cotton marketing project, field staff are selected by, responsible to, and compensated by the associations of local growers.
 - 31 - B. Selection Criteria and Methods Subprofessionals are usually selected on the basis of educational attainment, depending on the general educational levels of the country. Though a large number of farming activities are carried out by women, agricultural subprofessionals are usually men. Political patronage, ethnic affinity, and kinship connections often influence access to such positions, including entrance to the schools that provide the required credientials. They are chosen by competitive examination, enrolled for two or three years in a technical training institute and then employed by the Ministry ot Agriculture or a parastatal agency and assigned to the field. Usually, they are indigenous to the area in that they speak the local language or dialect and understand local conditions, but this is not invariably the case. Members of the local public have no voice in the selection of subprofessional civil servants. They are considered agents of the state, not of the local community. Since paraprofessionals must be able to work compatibly with local publics and are always indigenous people, local communities are sometimes consulted in their selection. Those consulted may be local officials or traditional chiefs, less often the entire community. Most observers agree that the effectiveness oE agency paraprofessionals depends on an active role by the local community in their selection. Project beneficiaries must have confidence in the persons who serve them. Since local communities are often socially stratified, government agencies should attempt to insure that the consultations includes a broad spectrum of the publics with whom the paraprofessional will work 17/. In fragmented communities it may be necessary to engage a separate paraprofessional for each segment of a seriously divided local population. Where the community pays, or the paraprofessionals are accountable to a local organization, as in the case of the Peasant Associations in Ethiopia,
 - 32 - the latter select the paraprofessionals from their own ranks. The choice of most agency paraprofessionals, including the T and V contact farmers, is made by government staff, usually the subprofessional under whose direction they will work. The important factors are motivation for service and the respect of neighbors. In some circumstances and for some tasks illiteracy is no bar to a person who is otherwise well equipped. A middle-age person or couple who are permanently identified with a community may command local confidence more than a better educated but less compatible young man or woman, though the required training period may be longer. The factor of gender deserves more attention that it usually receives. Since a large proportion of farm work is done by women and the customs of some societies preclude or seriously inhibit extra familial contact between men and women, there is a strong case for preferring women in many paraprofessional roles, especially when they are aiding or assisting in farming activities usually performed by women. Frequently, the operational needs of field staff are not among the priorities of departmental headquarters, whose information systems do not bring such problems and needs to the center's attention in time. Moreover, local communities and functional groups represent a vast resource for the self-provision of services and for multiplying the effectiveness of those provided by government. Therefore, one of the most interesting and potentially productive areas of sociological research and experimentation are local associations of rural people, formal and informal, and the means by which they can relate with government agencies, while providing many elements of service to their members through mutual assistance and collective effort. Frequently, this task requires a degree of sophistication that is beyond the capacity of most field staff unless they are specially trained for that task. My rough estimate is that five to seven agency patraprofessionals can usually be fielded at the same overall cost as one subprofessional civil servant. The substantial savings in
 - 42 - salary and fringe benefits costs are, however,significantly offset by the higher training, supervisory and monitoring costs required for effective field operations that rely heavily on paraprofessionals. In last instance, the main benefits of paraprofessional staffing are: 1. The much more intensive outreach, and coverage of rural publics than would otherwise be possible; 2. The employment of persons with greater ability to appreciate and respond to the needs of the groups they serve; and 3. Especially in the case of community paraprofessionals, the activation of local responsibility and self help. The financial case for paraprofessional staffing can probably not be made in absolute cost terms, but rather in terms of cost-effectiveness. The latter can be realized only through greater attention to local institutional development and the details of better project management. The question of comparative costs of alternative methods of field staffing is a prime candidate for future research. The desperate budget crises encountered by so many developing countries during the current period of international economic stagnation confront governments and donors with a specially difficult problem. Unfortunately, the shift in donor priorities to agricultural projects that emphasize productivity and employment among small holders has occurred at the same time that the budgets of host countries are under very great stress. To maintain even the present inadequate scale of rural public services may be difficult, for often the first items to be reduced are the material and transportation resources which enable field personnel to reach and serve their publics. While the employment of agency and especially of community paraprofessionals in support of small-scale farming is likely to be a cost-effective measure, it does entail some
 - 43 - incremental costs to government budgets. Donors, including the World Bank, should be prepared to finance for extended periods these incremental local currency expenditures, if they believe that the benefits of the project in productivity, incomes, or employment justify the increased locaL costs in tne first place. CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS This survey of field-level staffing in agricultural projects, drawing on World Bank experience, has touched on some, but by no means all the problems of field administration. Omitted, for example, have been the need to decentralize to the field greater authority to act and the related problem of field-level coordination among specialized bureaucratic agencies, subjects that require a separate paper 22/. Our point of departure was paraprofessionals -- an innovation in field administration that seeks to extend at relatively low cost the effective coverage of public services to rural people who could not otherwise be reached. We found that the functional equivalent of the agency paraprofessional as the last link in the bureaucratic chain is the community paraprofessional - a member of a local community selected by and accountable to his neighbors. This suggests the many alternatives and options that are available for field-level staffing of agricultural projects - beyond the conventional subprofessional technicians - and opens up some of the larger issues of how to provide effective and responsive agricultural services at reasonable cost to rural publics. That service to farmers at the field level, especially to the large and important constituency of small and marginal farmers, is a weak link in many agricultural development projects (even when physical infrastructure and appropriate technologies are available) is recognized by knowledgeable observers of rural development. It is at the nexus between the government agency and its rural publics that agriculturally oriented delivery systems frequently break down. Having been neglected by scholars, by governments and by donor agencies, including the World Bank, this is a subject whose time may finally have come. In the new emphasis on institution-building or
 - 45 - institutional development, both at the Bank and at USAID, attention is focusing on strengthening field-level institutions, both the state's bureaucratic structures and local organizations of small farmers and their families. Included in this broad topic is the division and sharing of responsibilities and taskcs between local farmer organizations, government agencies, and private coimmercial networks in an effort to achieve more effective "local action capabilities" 23/. Government-wide administrative policies, practices and regulations that impinge on field operations will have to be taken into account and modified where possible, but the main emphasis should be on strengthening field-level capacities and on program-specific incremental improvements that draw on all available organizatiorLal resources. In this framework, field-level staffing is a primary ccomponent - the selection, posting, training, support and management of personnel equipped and motivated to provide responsive and timely services, often with and through formal and informal organizations of local farmers. The term "bureaucratic reorientation" has recently been coined to express the need for greatly improved performance in field operations and the attention that must be devoted to the details of staff performance by those in direct contact with small farmers and their organizations 24/. As with most complex problems, especially those that require changes in human behavior and in social institutions, there can be no quick fixes in this area. Governtents will have to be persuaded to attach higher priority to field operations than they have been willing to in the past, if they expect to see progress in the smallholders' sector. They may have to consider changes in operating procedures that they have resisted, including the delegation to better trained and better motivated field staff of greater authority to act so that more timely accommodation can be made to specific local demands and needs of farmers and their families.
 - 46 - The Bank's experience with field-level staffing of agricultural projects indicates that governments and international donors should devote more attention to the details of project implementation. Without neglecting implementation at the headquarters and intermediate levels of government, much greater emphasis needs to be directed to the field, at the interface between government agencies and the local users of services, both men and women, whom projects are designed to help. The requirements of implementation should be envisaged at the design stage of projects and assessed during the process of project appraisal. That they can be left out at design stage, and somehow be adequately taken care of during subsequent implementation is a myth, refuted by three decades of experience. The working assumption should be just the opposite: that without a specific and detailed implementation plan the project will probably run into trouble. This is especially true of the software elements of projects that involve contact with, and social and behavioral change among, large numbers of people. Do means exist for reaching these farmers with the services the project will provide? Are there sufficient incentives to induce farmers to use the services? Are the staff providing these services adequately equipped and supported and attuned to the circumstances and capabilities of the particular farmers whom they address? The development of a detailed operational plan and the establishment of a monitoring system to check on the processes of implementation as well as on project outputs should be a required component of every Bank-sponsored project design - a test of administrative and socio-cultural feasibility. Process monitoring can provide the information that permits organizational learning - timely adjustments to events that were unanticipated in operational planning. This discipline can serve as an element of technical assistance to governments, strengthening their institutional capacities to plan and carry out future projects, whether or not they are supported by the Bank.
 - 47 - Implementation plans must deal with questions of organization and procedures, many of which are beyond the scope of this paper. On the vital question of field-level staffing, much can be done by the national agencies. as well as by international aid and technical assistance agencies, to promote the cost-effectiveness in the management of agricultural projects. The following propositions should be taken into account in assessing provisions for the field-level staffing of agricultural projects: 1. Governments are unlikely to be able to afford to provide agricultural services to the mass of small and marginal farmers and pastoralists through full-time, fully trained, civil servants. In addition, governments as well as the Bank or other aid agencies are understandably concerned with limiting the recurrent costs of projects. 2. To control recurrent budget costs while expanding services that enhance productivity and employment, project designers should draw on all available local action capabilities, including private sector commercial networks and local organizations of farmers. It is especially important, as agricultural services expand, to limit the employment and control the costs of conventional civil service personnel, particularly subprofessional staff. 3. Local paraprofessionals provide a means by which many services can be extended at relatively low cost to rural publics. Such indigenous, usually part-time people, may enjoy better rapport with local cultivators, be better informed of local needs and capabilities, and be more effective for many roles (as indicated in Chart: 1) than full-time, relatively expensive civil service staff, even if the latter were available.
 - 48 - a) Whenever agricultural projects must reach large numbers of small farmers, consideration should be given to including paraprofessionals in the project. b) Paraprofessionals may be either unifunctional or polyvalent. They should in any case start with a limited range of functions which can be expanded after the initial tasks have been mastered. c) Jobs should be redesigned and simplified so that they can be handled by relatively uneducated local paraprofessionals with limited practical training. d) Normally, local communities and members of the affected publics should be consulted and directly involved in the selection of paraprofessional personnel. e) Since they are an important component of the agricultural work force, women should be chosen for paraprofessional roles when the principal publics are likely to be women. f) To be effective, paraprofessionals require practical, job-related training, both in technical and communications skills. This training must be periodically or continuously reinforced. Facilities for preentry and in-service training should be specifically incorporated into project design. g) Paraprofessionals also require supervision, support, and dependable sources of information and material inputs, all of which should be built into project design. Subprofessional roles and skills should be modified to take account of the increasing presence of paraprofessionals as the front line providers of many services. Thus, subprofessionals should be retrained and motivated to provide the back-up supervision, reinforcement and managerial support for paraprofessional staff.
 - 49 - h) While volunl:ary service may be an important motivation, paraprofessLonals usually require some modest material compensatioIl or perquisites, even when they serve on a part-time basis. Agency paraprofessionals should receive small payments from government; community paraprofessionals can be compensated, at least in part, by local farmers organizations. 4. Wherever possible, responsibility for project management should be shared with project beneficiaries through their local associations: a) Local organizations can mobilize and contribute labor and material resources, provide government agencies with reliable information and feedback on local needs and capabilities, and retail services and resources at low cost to their members. They can and should participate in the design and ongoing management and modification of local project activities, thus accepting greater responsibility for their own development. b) Members of the local organization selected by, responsible to, and compensated by their peers, can serve as community paraprofessionals. They can provide services which complement those made available by government staff, thus reducing burdens on the government's budget and on its administrative resources and enhancing community or group self-reliance. c) One function of p. oject personnel is to develop and work with and through local organizations of project beneficiaries. In many cases, they must help to activate these organizations, though this is not their greatest strength. Private voluntary organizations and fully qualified professionals specially prepared fcr this task are usually more effective in activating local groups.
 - 50 - 5. The Bank and other international aid agencies could certainly help government agencies to improve the ability of locally-based staff members to work compatibly and responsively with organized publics. a) The development of appropriate skills will, in many cases, represent a substantial reorientation of bureaucratic attitudes, procedures and behavior and require changes in prevailing job requirements, expectations and rewards. Such assistance in management improvement and institutional development should be specifically incorporated into project design when estimates of administrative feasibility disclose the need for such measures. b) Because of the acute pressure on government budgets during the current period of international economic stagnation, the Bank should be prepapred to finance the incremental costs of training, supervising, supporting, and compensating agricultural professionals. 6. A vital contribution of the Bank to the success of agricultural projects is to support improved training facilities and programs for all categories of field staff, including agency paraprofessionals, community paraprofessionals, and subprofessional personnel. a) Such training should be practical, job related and provide for periodic reinforcement; it should include technical, communications, and social skills. b) The retraining of subprofessionals in supervisory and management skills is an important training priority to which the Bank's assistance should be directed.
 - 51 - c) Regional agricultural centers provide an effective way to combine referral facilities, sources of project inputs, and field experimentation with the supervision and training of field staff. It is important that training and support activities be specifically incorporated into project: design and monitored continuously during project implementation. International donors, including the World Bank, could contribute to the effectiveness of agricultural projects by paying much more attention to the details of project implementation, to institutional developmient at the local level, and especia'Lly to field staffing. The cases analyzed in this review indicate that such a change may already be underway, but the Bank is far more advanced in its appreciation of the potential utility of local farmer organizations than in met:hods to improve the structure and procedures of bureaucratic agencies and of field-level personnel. As the Worl.d Bank has helped to reorient the development priorities of its member countries in the direction of agricultura:L and rural development and towards the needs and potentials of small-scale producers, it can similarly help to reorient them to the importance of field-level institutional development in support of broadly-based rural deve:Lopment. To do so will require explicit consideration of these issues in the preparation and appraisa:L of projects and consequent pressure on implementing agencies. Far more atteution will have to be devoted to the det:ails of administrative and institutional feasibility and to field-level staffing at the point where projects engage their intended beneficiaries. This will entail greater capacity and higher priority along these lines among the Bank's own staff, particularly among those who participate in the design and
 - 52 - supervise the implementation of agricultural projects. Some of this enhanced capacity on issues of field-level implementation may be available from outside contractors and consultants, but these can not substitute fully for greater capacity, priority and sensitivity on the Bank's core staff. After substantial investments and various experiences with agricultural projects, the Bank has arrived to a recognition of the complexity of the problems of field-level management, the need for detailed institutional and sociological analysis at the stages of project design and implementation, and the many options and combinations of staffing methods that may be available in specific project environments. Much more precise information is needed to guide decisions, especially on the various options for field-level staffing. An intensive experimental and learning focus on this range of problems by the unique array of resources available to the Bank could have a beneficial effect on the state-of-the-art, on the effectiveness of project performance, and on the eventual productivity and welfare of millions of small farm families.

doc.repnme: Paraprofessionals in rural development : issues in field-level staffing for agricultural projects
doc.abstracts: Sociological and institutional problems of implementing small-scale agriculture projects have been neglected, particularly in connection with implementation at the field level. Cost-effectiveness of agricultural projects can be increased by innovations in field level staffing. The Bank has already begun to support projects that employ paraprofessional staff in agricultural extension, irrigation, livestock, and forestry development. Lessons learned from this include: (i) consultation with project beneficiaries in the choice of paraprofessionals; (ii) employment of female paraprofessionals to assist in the performance of farming roles normally played by women; (iii) preservice and frequent refresher training in practical, job-related information and skills; and (iv) reliable referral, logistical, and supervisory support for paraprofessional staff. Paraprofessionals selected by, compensated by, and accountable to local organizations and associations of farmers can increase the relevance and cost-effectiveness of services while enhancing local self-reliance.
